Title: If a group is the union of two subgroups, is one subgroup the group itself?
Content: "Let $G$ be a group, and suppose $G=H \cup K$, where $H$ and $K$ are subgroups.  Show that either $H=G$ or $K=G$." Let $h \in H$ and $k \in K$.  Then $hk \in H$ or $hk \in K$ (since every element of $G$ is in either $H$ or $K$).  If $hk=h'$ for some $h' \in H$, then $k=h^{-1}h'$, so $k \in H$.  If $hk=k'$ for some $k' \in K$, then $h=k'k^{-1}$ so that $h \in K$. If for all $h \in H$ we have $h \in K$, or if for all $k \in K$ we have $k \in H$, then $H \subseteq K$ or $K \subseteq H$.  Then since $G=H \cup K$, we must have either $H=G$ or $K=G$. I'm not sure if the first paragraph of my 'proof' implies the second.  I've shown that for arbitrary $h \in H$, $h \in H$ and possibly $h \in K$, and similar for $k \in K$.  I don't know how to wrap it up (or perhaps this route won't lead anywhere at all). If this way won't work, I'd just like a hint on a new direction to take. Thanks.
AcceptedAnswer: Suppose both $H,K$ are distinct and proper in $G$. Then pick $h\in H\setminus K$ and $k\in K\setminus H$. In which of $K$ or $H$ or both does $hk$ lie?
